intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Today's topic is about managing stress.

We know how stressful it is to bring up teenagers in these times. Learning to manage your stress helps you – and your family.

With a few small changes, you can feel more peaceful in your normal day-to-day life.

When you are peaceful, your family members will get calmer too!
Let’s look at an example of how stress can sometimes just get too much, for all of us:

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are a few skills to help you manage stress that you can use with your teens!

Here is your home activity for this week:

Whenever you are feeling stressed or upset with your teen, take five breaths in and out before you react.

And when you're both calm, share with each other how you feel.
intros.text_2::eng:
**Remember to:** 

😮‍💨 BREATHE: take five breaths in and out before you react
🤝🏾 SHARE: when you're both calm, share with your teen how you feel
💙 SHOW: ask them how they feel to show you care
🔍 SEEK: find something positive in this situation together
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng:

🔍 SEEK: find something positive in this situation together

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng: Remember, when we practice responding calmly and sharing how we feel, our teens learn to do the same. This skill will help them their whole life!

Today's topic is about giving positive instructions!

Telling our teens what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

You will see the difference.

When you give positive instructions, your teen is more likely to listen! 

And remember to praise your teen for any good behaviour - the big and small things.

Let’s do a thought experiment!

DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT.

What are you thinking about? 

You probably DID think about an elephant...
intros.text_2::eng:
In the same way, when we tell our teens “don’t do that,” they often focus only on the thing we told them not to do.
They may not understand what we *DO* want.

And like most of us, they don’t enjoy being told what not to do.
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng:
In the same way, when we tell our teens “don’t do that,” they often focus only on the thing we told them not to do.
They may not understand what we *DO* want.

And like most of us, they don’t enjoy being told what not to do.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH!

What are you thinking about?

That’s right! Positive, clear instructions help teens focus on what they should be doing.

Teens will also feel more respected this way and are more likely to listen.

Today's topic is about calm consequences.

Our actions have consequences. Some consequences happen naturally (“if you break something, you can’t use it anymore”). Other consequences we set as a family to motivate us to follow the rules (“if you come home late, you can’t go out with friends tomorrow”).

HOW you set and use consequences together matters.

Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.

🎉 CONGRATULATIONS! 

You have done it! You have built lots of important parenting skills.

This is a huge achievement. It shows such care for your family.

Let’s celebrate you and plan your future @global.app_name support.
Calm consequences work best when they are fair, agreed on together, and followed through consistently - not in anger.

Luckily, there are ways to discipline without getting angry or using violence… and they work well!

Giving calm consequences is important because it helps teens learn from their actions and take responsibility for their choices.

Today's topic is about family budgets.

Many families are stressed about money, especially if teens keep asking for things!

When we make a budget together, we can agree how to spend AND save to prevent stress and work towards our family’s goals.
When we involve our teens in budgeting, they learn to be responsible with money and work towards goals. That is something we all want for our teens, right?

It can be hard to make ends meet every month. Many families have this problem!

Including @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name – let's have a look:

Dealing with money challenges, like @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name's situation, is stressful. 

A family budget can help @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name - and YOU!
intros.text_2::eng:
**There are four steps for doing a family budget:**

💭 Step 1: THINK 
🎯 Step 2: CHOOSE 
⚒️  Step 3: BUILD 
📋 Step 4: PLAN
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng:
**There are four steps for doing a family budget:**

💭 Step 1: THINK 
🎯 Step 2: CHOOSE 
⚒️  Step 3: BUILD 
📋 Step 4: PLAN

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 1: THINK**
Think about what you spend money on each month.
intros.text_2::eng:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 2: CHOOSE**
Think about your needs and wants.
- WANT is something you can live without. 
- NEED is something you cannot live without.
intros.text_2::eng:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 3: BUILD**
Make a budget!
intros.text_2::eng:
- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. For example: If your income is R2000 and you have 20 beans, each bean is R100.
- Decide what you will spend on, and put the stones/objects on that image.

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine! This exercise will get easier with practice.
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng:
- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. For example: If your income is R2000 and you have 20 beans, each bean is R100.
- Decide what you will spend on, and put the stones/objects on that image.

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine! This exercise will get easier with practice.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
**Step 4: PLAN**
Plan how you can save money, so you can deal with emergencies and realise your family goals!
intros.text_2::eng:
If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or emergency - it can make a big difference over time.

- Add a circle called “emergencies”.
- Add a circle called “family goals”.
- Now try to move your money around so you can save a bit every month for goals and emergencies.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
CONGRATULATIONS!!! 🎉 

You have made your budget! Remember to do this exercise again with your other family members - if you agree on a plan together it will make a huge difference!

Having a savings plan could have helped @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name to be prepared for this kind of emergency! 

There are different ways we can save: at home, by buying things we can sell for profit, at a bank, or in a stokvel.

Think of the advantages and disadvantages of each savings option.

We all have dreams for our family, just like @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name. By setting aside a bit of money every month, you can realise them too!

Let’s come up with some ideas for savings goals for you to make a budget plan.
Here are this week’s takeaway skills to help you budget and save!

This week's home practice is to make a budget again - this time WITH your teen and family!

This is an important and fun thing to do with your family - it takes about 30 minutes.

🎯 Step 2: CHOOSE (what are our needs and wants?)
⚒️ Step 3: BUILD (make your budget) 
📋 Step 4: PLAN (plan for emergencies and family goals)

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
When we involve teens in budgeting, they learn important life skills, like understanding the difference between needs and wants.

Making a budget together also helps teens see that we all need to make hard choices sometimes, but that it helps us to have enough money at the end of the month - and to realise our goals!

Today’s topic is about solving problems.

Every family has challenges, but working together helps us find calm, good solutions — at home, at school, in the community and online.

As parents, we sometimes think we need to fix every problem by ourselves. And teens can think the same! 

By involving your teen, you strengthen your relationship as well as their confidence. Together you can overcome anything.

Problem-solving together is an important skill for every family. Let’s see how @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and @data.characters.f2_son_15.name handle a problem calmly and find a plan together.

Then, try to handle the problem using these four steps!

Now let’s try problem-solving ourselves.

Before, she worried alone, now they can come up with solutions together!

When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame. But what our teens really need is someone to help find solutions together. 

Listen to them, accept how they see and feel things, and thank them for trusting you.

Teaching your teen how to deal with problems will help them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

We all have problems, but they don’t define us! You can choose to address challenges and try different solutions together with your teen. 
This shows your teen that they are never alone and gives them a key skill to use at home, with friends, and for life!

Today’s topic is about teen safety.

Teens can spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe. Talking together about safe and unsafe places — and how to prevent problems — really helps.

This guidance is important for both girls and boys so they learn to make responsible choices that protect themselves and others.

Sometimes our teens notice things about their surroundings that we don’t. By talking and listening, we can better understand their world and guide them through challenges – including the risks they face online.

With our support, they can learn to stay safe and make good decisions.

The most important way to help keep your teen safe is to make sure that they know they can talk to you about anything. 

Work with your teen to notice risks — like when someone pressures or makes them feel uncomfortable, online or offline.

Boys experience sexual abuse almost as often as girls, so talk openly with both about staying safe.

Let’s look at examples of risky situations to help you spot warning signs.

Let’s get practical now, and draw two maps of safe and unsafe places:

- 🌐 A map of apps/websites we use online
Step 1: Draw all the important places in your community.

Remember to include your phone and other internet devices, as mobile apps and websites are also places where you and your teen can spend a lot of time!

Here are some skills to help you keep your teen safe!

If you have not done it together yet, this week's home assignment is to make two maps with your teen of safe and unsafe places:

1) 🗺️ Map of your community
2) 🌐 Map of apps and websites your teen uses

Make sure you are both happy with the safety plan. What really matters is that you talk with your teen as you do this – often teens know much more than we do about where it is safe and unsafe!

When teens know they can turn to us without fear, they are more likely to ask for help when something feels unsafe - both offline and online. Talking calmly and making safety plans together builds trust that lasts.

Today’s lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child’s actions. When children don’t follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

Some consequences happen naturally – like when a toy breaks, it can’t be used.

Others are set by you to help your child follow rules (_“if you don’t pack away your toys, you can’t play with them tomorrow”_). 

Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_father.name uses consequences to help his son, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, follow instructions:

Today’s topic is about helping your child learn and grow.

Play helps children learn what is expected and how to get along with others. It supports their development, both in school and at home.

This is true for all children, including those who are shy, have a disability, or struggle to keep up in class.

@data.characters.f3_mother.name knows that children learn best by playing. 
She wants to help her son, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, grow and stay curious by spending more time playing together. Let’s see how she does it.
@data.characters.f3_mother.name helped her son learn by playing together. Let’s explore how she did this.
intros.text_2::eng:
@data.characters.f3_mother.name helped her son learn new skills by:
- ⚽ **Playing with him**: This let @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn through doing. @data.characters.f3_mother.name didn’t need to show him how to build a house, he figured it out on his own.
- 🏆 **Letting him lead**: She allowed him to ask questions and explore. Curiosity helps children become confident and creative.
- 👏🏾 **Praising him**: She showed him that being curious and trying ideas is a good thing.

Every family faces challenges. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you when you have conflict in your home. 

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!

4) 💭 REFLECT: See if it worked. If not, try another solution

Today’s topic is praise.

Praise is a great way to guide our teens in all parts of life — at home, with friends, or online.

If we praise our teens when they do something well, we will see them do more and more positive things!
Praise is an easy way to build your teen’s confidence and strengthen your connection. It really works!

Praise really is powerful.

Many parents want to help their teens but find it difficult to talk about sensitive topics, like body changes and relationships.
intros.text_2::eng: Here are some questions from other parents to help you begin.
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng: Here are some questions from other parents to help you begin.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
This is not quite right. 

Remember, friends can sometimes mislead or have wrong information themselves.

This is not quite right. 

Your teen might feel uncomfortable or scared to start that conversation with you.

Yes, you may need to start the conversation - and it’s okay to feel shy. Be open and use the right words for any body parts you discuss (like breasts, penis, or vagina).

You can practise with a friend and ask a health worker or social worker for more information. The more you know, the better you can help your teen.

And remember, it’s also okay not to know everything. You can say, “I’m not sure - let me find out and tell you later.”

intros.text_2::eng: Other parents also wonder:

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
That’s not quite right.

Teens need to learn about body changes and relationships early, so they are prepared and can make good choices.

If you find out your teen is having sex, try to stay calm and share your worries gently. Getting angry can make it harder for your teen to talk to you.

Age 10 is when a lot of children start to enter puberty, so they need to already understand how their bodies and feelings may change.

This will also help them cope better with sexual feelings safely.

That's right! 

Age 10 is when a lot of children start to enter puberty, so they need to already understand how their bodies and feelings may change.

This will also help them cope better with sexual feelings safely.

It’s good to start talking about body changes and relationships early - by gently answering your child’s questions.

You don’t need to explain everything. Just give simple, honest answers that match their age and understanding.

intros.text_2::eng: Many parents also ask:

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
This may not work.

When we try to control too much, teens may do the opposite of what we want.

But when we guide them and give them space to make choices – both online and offline – they often act more responsibly.

This may not work. 

Teens get pressure and information from many places we can’t control.

As parents, we can guide and prepare them to know what is right or wrong – and help them feel confident to make good decisions in their day-to-day life and online.

That’s right.

When your teen feels trusted, they are more likely to trust you and come to you for advice or help when something happens online, at school, or in the community..

Praise and thank them when they share. Avoid judging, so they feel safe to talk to you again.

That’s right.

Good decisions come from thinking through the consequences. Talk openly with your teen when there’s a problem. Listen to each other and find solutions together.

Each challenge is an opportunity to teach your teen that actions have consequences—and you can handle them as a team.

Remember to praise each other for working through tough situations together.

That’s right.

To stay safe, your teen needs to know the difference between respectful behaviours and relationships, and unhealthy ones..

Respectful relationships feel caring, safe, and fair – both online and offline. Unhealthy ones involve pressure, discomfort, or feeling unsafe.

No one should be forced to do something they’re not okay with.

That’s not quite right.

Teens hear many things about sex—from school, friends, or social media. Some of it is wrong.

Knowing about sex doesn’t mean they are having sex. Good information helps them stay safe and understand why waiting to have sex can be a good choice.

Without this knowledge, they may face problems, like not knowing how pregnancy happens or the risks of sex.

That’s not quite right.

Your teen might have a boyfriend or girlfriend and not tell you.

If you make them hide it, they may not come to you with questions or problems—and this can lead to risky situations.

That’s right.

Teens are figuring out who they are. They look to friends and media for answers, and may feel pressure to do things they’re not ready for.

Talk calmly with your teen about waiting to have sex until they feel ready, are in a safe relationship, and understand the consequences. Focus on guiding them calmly to make healthy choices.

Now let's practise making rules.

Write down one important rule you would like to make with your teenager – you will be doing this as your home practice this week.
intros.text_2::eng:
**Here are some examples of rules other families made:**
- ⚽ Teen can play outside after finishing homework
- 👪🏽 All family members eat dinner together
- 💬 We talk about anything that worries us – no keeping secrets.
- 📱 We use phones responsibly – no phones at bedtime and only private accounts.
- ❤️ We treat others with respect, online and offline.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
This week's home activity is to set one rule together with your teen.

Remember to praise your teen afterwards!
intros.text_2::eng:
**Remember to use your skills for rule setting:**

⚽ Team rules: When making the rule, work together like a team. 
🔎 Real rules: Agree on real rules that are clear and fair. For example, you could agree that everyone says where they are going before leaving the house.
🎉 Praise rules: Praise when rules are followed!
💛 Relationship rules: Make rules to guide safe choices in relationships and online.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng: Clear, simple rules made together with your teen are not about control - they are about keeping them safe and building responsibility. When teens understand the reasons behind the rules, they are more likely to follow them.

Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

Let's discuss, what is one-on-one time?

One-on-one time is when you focus on your teens, without distractions like TVs or phones. Let your teens take the lead in choosing what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can spend fifteen minutes a day together, but even five minutes a day is really good.
Helping with schoolwork is one simple way to start. Let’s see how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_daughter_12.name do this together.

intros.text_2::eng: _5 minutes later..._
intros.text_2_facilitator::eng: _5 minutes later..._

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
@data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_daughter_12.name showed us how one-on-one time can be simple and fun. They listened to each other, shared tasks, and laughed together.
Now, let’s think about what made this time successful for them — and why it matters when both mothers and fathers spend time with their teens.
Here are some skills to help guide you in spending one-on-one time with your teen!

Spending one-on-one time with your teen can be hard to plan. 

**Remember to use your new skills:**
📅 **DAY**: try to do it every day
⚽ **PLAY**: let your teen choose how to spend one-on-one time  
🎯 **STAY**: be focused on your teen
📓 **LEARN**: connect with your teen — this helps them learn!
This week's home activity is to spend 5-15 minutes of one-on-one time with your teen, every day that you can.

Remember, spending even a few minutes of one-on-one time with your teen each day can strengthen your relationship and build trust. 

Listening closely and sharing small moments helps teens feel loved and supported.

Today's topic is about taking care of yourself.

We often don’t look after ourselves enough. But this is so important, especially as a parent!

Reducing our stress and treating ourselves well helps us AND our teenagers.

Why self-care?

We often don’t look after ourselves enough. But this is so important, especially as a parent!

Reducing our stress and treating ourselves well helps us AND our teenagers.

Today’s topic is dealing with crises.

All families face crises. When we prepare together and know where to get help before something happens, we can handle it more calmly and confidently.

Crises can be scary, but you can get through them together.

Appreciating ourselves is one way to care for ourselves. 

Let’s give it a try.
Every crisis is a challenge, but it is also a chance to grow stronger as a family and show your teen that together, you can get through anything.

Treating ourselves well is another way of looking after ourselves.

You can give yourself a small reward every day, and it does not have to cost a thing!

Crisis can happen to anyone.

Let's see what happened with @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and her granddaughter, @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name:

You cannot pour from an empty cup! That is why it is important to care for ourselves. When both parents rest and relax, everyone in the family feels better!
Let’s see how parents can support each other to do this too.
Here are some tips to help you take care of yourself.

Remember: Small moments of self-care matter. This week, find time to relax, recognize your efforts, and reward yourself whenever you can.
 
Care for yourself every day. You deserve it!

This was such a difficult situation for @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name and her @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name!  

Let's think about how @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name supported @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name through this crisis.

Remember, taking small moments for self-care helps us stay calm, strong, and connected to our families. 

When we look after ourselves, we are better able to support our teens!

Crisis can make us feel angry or helpless. But this is when our teens really need us to breathe, listen and think. 

Here are some tips to help you deal with a crisis!

It is helpful to practise dealing with crises before something happens.

Let's look at five family crisis examples together. Imagine you are the parent: What would you do?

Remember: CONNECT - BREATHE - LISTEN - THINK

Crisis 1: @data.characters.f2_son_15.name fights at school.

How could you respond to @data.characters.f2_son_15.name?

Crisis 2: @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name gets pregnant.

How could you respond to @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name?

Crisis 3: @data.characters.f1_son_18.name makes a girl pregnant.

How could you respond to @data.characters.f1_son_18.name?

Crisis 4: Someone in the family may get sick.

How could you respond in this situation?

Crisis 5: @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name is pressured into sex by her boyfriend.

How could you respond to @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name?
This week's home activity is to look back at the five crisis examples and discuss what you would do together if this happened to a friend or in your family.

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng: Remember to support and encourage each other. It is hard to remain calm and listen to each other in a crisis - you can be proud of yourself.

Teens spend lots of time online to learn, have fun, and connect with friends. It can help them grow, but also brings risks.
As parents, we don’t need to know every new app — what matters most is trust. When we listen and guide with care, our teens feel safe to share. 
Let’s keep them safe together!

When we explore the online world together, we understand our teens better. It shows them that online safety is about trust and support, not control.
Learning simple steps as a family builds confidence and helps teens make good choices.
For teens, the online world feels just as real and important as the offline world.

Talking about online safety can feel hard. Many parents don’t know how to begin. A good start is to show interest in what your teen enjoys online. Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_son_14.name’s mother does this…

We saw how @data.characters.f1_son_14.name and his mother talked openly about his time online.
Being online can help teens learn, create, and connect — but we also need to guide them to stay safe and use it wisely.
Here are 4 things you can discuss with your teen about online safety:

Sometimes teens run into tricky or even dangerous situations online, and as parents it’s not always easy to know what to do.

Let’s look at 5 examples of online warning signs and how we can support our teens.
intros.text_2::eng: **Warning Sign 1: Lerato is quiet and withdrawn — a change in mood can signal something is wrong.**

**Warning Sign 2: @data.characters.f3_daughter_12.name hears about a classmate sharing private photos — hearing such stories is a warning sign to talk with your teen about pressure and safety online.**
**Warning Sign 3: @data.characters.f1_son_18.name is being threatened online — fear and threats are warning signs of sextortion or blackmail.**
**Warning Sign 4: @data.characters.friend_male_4.name shared private pictures at school — sharing or showing harmful images is a warning sign that teens need clear guidance.**
**Warning Sign 5: @data.characters.f2_son_15.name gets a message from a stranger while showing his grandpa his game. When strangers offer gifts or ask to chat, it’s a warning sign.**

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng: Keeping your teen safe online starts with understanding their experiences. Let’s come up with easy ways to get involved in your teen’s world online.
intros.text_2::eng:
**Here are some examples of shared online moments:**

🖥️ Watch a short video or song together
💜 Share memes and funny clips
😊 Ask your teen to teach you something online (like posting a family photo)
💬 Ask “Did you see anything fun or interesting online today?” 
📓 Help with research or homework online

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng: Here are some tips to help you with online safety:

This week’s activity is to make an Online Family Agreement with your teen. 

When you create rules together, teens feel part of the team — not controlled — and are more likely to follow them.
intros.text_2::eng:
**Sit with your teen and make 5 rules for safe and fun online time.
Stick them on the wall when you’re done!**
👩‍👩‍👦 When both mom and dad join in, your teen sees that everyone helps keep the family safe ❤️.

**Sample Online Family Agreement**

Our family agrees to these rules for safe and fun online time:
🔑 Keep accounts private
🚩 Do not share school, address, or phone number
✅ Ask permission before sharing photos of others
⏰ No phones during meals or at bedtime
☀️ Be kind and respectful to others online
😃 Share one positive or funny post or video with the family each week
💛 Teens: I will talk to an adult if anything feels wrong or uncomfortable online
✨ Parents: I will listen and support my teens without judging or blaming

Signed by:
🔶 Parent / caregiver __________
🔷 Teen __________

intros.text_1_facilitator::eng:
Online risks can look different for boys and girls. They may hide or act out in different ways. When we blame or punish, they stop sharing — and the risk grows.

You don’t need to know everything. The best way to keep your teen safe is to build trust, stay calm, and let them know they can always come to you for help.

media.media_title::eng: Can managing stress help you and your family? Tap play to find out
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone.

Today's topic is managing stress.

It is important to know how to manage our stress. At times our children can behave in ways that make us feel stressed and us as parents can make our children feel stressed too.

So, it is important to notice when we feel stressed and take a pause and breathe. That will help you manage your stress.

media.media_title::eng: Pause, take a breath. Now hear how taking a simple pause helped @data.characters.media_female_4.name and her teens
media.media_transcript::eng:
Life is tough sometimes. Before I joined @global.app_name, I used to be grumpy at all times. I would take out my anger on everyone at home, not only my teens but even my husband as well. They would run away when I came home because they knew I would start yelling at them.

Learning to take a pause and breathe was difficult at first. But every time I tried it, it helped me to calm down. Now my teens are no longer running away when I come home and they actually listen better than when I used to shout at them!

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_son_1.name learned to stay calm from his father
media.media_transcript::eng:
Whenever I would do something wrong, my father would get so angry at me and beat me. He would not even listen to me and I would get so angry as well at him and everyone else.

Now, when he gets angry, he first takes a few deep breaths before he responds. It makes everyone calm down instead of causing a big fight.

It really helped me at home and at school, because even me I am no longer slashing at everyone and I am no longer this moody person. When I feel really angry or stressed, I also take deep breaths like my father does. I am a different person.

media.media_title::eng: Giving positive instructions really works! Tap play to learn more
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, greetings everyone.

Today our topic is positive instructions.

It is important to give positive instructions to our children, because when we give them positive instructions they know and understand what we are expecting them to do and they do it the way we want them to do it.

So, at the end it keeps everyone happy.

media.media_title::eng: Press play to hear how positive instructions worked for @data.characters.media_female_3.name and her teens
media.media_transcript::eng:
Before, I used to raise my teens the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learnt about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my teens. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “don’t do this.”

My teens and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My teen said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how positive instructions helped @data.characters.media_daughter_3.name and her mother
media.media_transcript::eng:
At first, I did not care much that my mother was using with @global.app_name. But then I started to see my mother change how she communicated with us.

One day, when I was going out with my friends, she said I must be home by 6pm. I was like “Hmmm okay,” because she normally did not give clear instructions on what she wanted – she would just say nothing and then shout at me for being late when I got home.

When I got home around 5pm, my mother gave me a hug and said “Thank you for being on time.” It was strange, but I liked it.

Since then, we have much clearer communication in the house.

media.media_title::eng: How will introducing calm consequences help you and your family? Play to learn more
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is calm consequences.

It is important that when we introduce consequences to our teenagers we involve them, but also important that we are calm when we introduce consequences.

That will assist us to agree on introducing calm consequences to our teenagers, and our teenagers will easily remember them when they are involved and that will make them responsible.

media.media_title::eng: Let's celebrate our journey together and all your achievements!
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone.

Today’s topic is celebration and next steps.

It has been amazing, it has been wonderful having you on this journey. Today we are celebrating our journey together.

Today we are celebrating all the learnings that we have learnt throughout this time together.

Now, let's think of the next steps. What could be the next steps after this? Maybe we are planning to continue all the learnings that we have learnt here. We don't know, we are hoping that for the next steps, the skills, the learnings will continue. We wish you a pleasant, happy, family time. 

Thank you.

media.media_title::eng: Agreeing on consequences together works! Tap play to hear @data.characters.media_female_13.name tell her story
media.media_transcript::eng:
When my teenagers did something to make me angry, I would shout at them and punish them right away. But the next time they did it again! I could not understand why they did not hear me even when I shouted.

@global.app_name helped me understand that my teenagers will listen to me more when I am calm. So, when something happens, I take a deep breath and say “we will talk about this later when we are both calm.”

We even agree on the consequences together now before something goes wrong. This has worked wonders – I have seen a huge change in my teen’s behaviour now that they are more involved, and I have less stress.

I wish I knew this long ago, but it is never too late to start!

media.media_title::eng: You've done an amazing job. Tap play to reflect on how far you've come
media.media_transcript::eng:
Close your eyes and relax.

Think of your family life before you started your journey with this app.

Think back on skills you learned:

Self-care
One-on-one time
Praise
Positive instructions
Managing stress
Family budgeting
Rules
Calm consequences

Teen safety
Dealing with crisis
Reflect on the journey – how was it for you to:

Share ideas and experiences
Reflect on and learn from the stories

Did anything change for you and your family?

What do you need to continue to use skills?

media.media_title::eng: Tap play to hear how @data.characters.media_daughter_6.name learned to appreciate calm consequences
media.media_transcript::eng:
My mom and dad would always punish me when they were angry with me. They would shout at me and I would also get angry. I often did not follow the rules, because they were too harsh, I did not understand what they were saying, or I would not even bother listening to them, because we were all angry.

One day, they asked me: Let's think together what the consequence should be for not coming home in time. It was great to give my view – before something happens that makes us all angry. We are all calm and agree first. It is easier for me to follow the rules now because I know I agreed on the rule and on the consequence if I do not follow the rule.

media.media_title::eng: Can creating family budgets help your family? Tap play to learn more
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is family budgeting.

It is important to create a budget, but it is even more important to create a budget involving the entire family.

Doing it together helps increase the level of understanding of how you spend money as a family and how much you save for the family and you can even come up with plans of how you can save as a family.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_6.name involved her teens in budgeting
media.media_transcript::eng:
Saving and budgeting helps me as a parent, and it helps my teens as well to understand where the money goes.

My teens always asked for a lot of things and they did not understand when I said “I do not have money.” They would say “but you have a job!”

I sat down with them and showed them all the things we pay for and how much is left. They understand now and even give ideas on how we can save to work towards our goals like new shoes or a birthday and bigger goals like their school fees. For the older one, I even opened a savings account.

media.media_title::eng: Can creating family budgets help your family? Tap play to learn more
media.media_transcript::eng:
I used to ask my mom to buy me nice clothes all the time. Each time, she would say “I do not have money,” but I knew that she was getting money from my uncle. I did not understand why she refused to buy me clothes. I thought at some point “she does not love me.”

But one day, she called me to sit down with her and asked “what are the needs and wants in our house.” I started to list all my needs and wants. Then my mother helped me to also think about the family needs. Now I understand where our money is going, towards the things we need as a family.

From that day, I understand I cannot come in and ask any time. Now, when I want something, I wait till the month-end when we all discuss the budget together to see if it fits. We understand each other better now.

media.media_title::eng: How can problem solving help you and your family?
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is problem solving.

We all know that in life there are times where we face problems, and we all know in a way that when we find ourselves in these situations, it is difficult to think of immediate positive solutions.

Therefore, it is important that when we are facing problems we take a pause, we breathe, keep calm and think of problem-solving skills that we may use.

media.media_title::eng: Can problem solving keep your teens safe? It did for @data.characters.media_female_4.name - tap play to hear her story
media.media_transcript::eng:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school.

Only when I started spending One-on-One time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the 6 steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.

media.media_title::eng: Can you make an impact on your community with these skills? Hear @data.characters.media_son_2.name's story
media.media_transcript::eng:
When my father introduced the problem-solving steps to me, it helped me with my family, but it also helped me with my friends.

I told my friends about the steps, and now when we are arguing we sit down and everyone comes up with solutions. We then look for the negatives and positives of each solution, and we agree “okay let’s try this one.”

My friends even took it to their own homes, and it is helping with their families as well!

It is great when others listen to you and accept your ideas even though you are young. We can all bring that harmony with our friends and family.

media.media_title::eng: Why is teen safety important for you and your family?
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today our topic is teen safety.

It is our responsibility as parents to keep our teens safe at all times. We need to ensure that our teenagers are safe in the communities that we live in. It is our responsibility that we make them aware of the safe and unsafe areas in the communities.

media.media_title::eng: A safety plan helped @data.characters.media_female_8.name protect her teen. Tap play to hear more
media.media_transcript::eng:
I was so grateful to make the safety plan with my teen. I thought I knew which areas are safe for my teen and which are not. But when we made the safety plan together, I realised that my girl knew more areas that I was not aware of.

I also thought she was safe at school, but through this activity I realised she was being bullied and the teachers did not do anything about it.

The more we talked, the more I understood and got information from my teen. That really helped me to protect my teen and keep her safe.

media.media_title::eng: Safety planning helped @data.characters.media_daughter_7.name open up. Hear her story
media.media_transcript::eng:
When my friends or I got into trouble, I would always try to hide it from my mother because she would get so angry and shout at me.

When we made the map of safe and unsafe places, I learnt a lot – also why it is dangerous to share every picture online. My mother told me I can always ask her if there is a problem and she promised she would not get mad.

She kept her promise, so now if I have a problem or I do not feel safe I know we can always come up with a solution together. I can even talk to my mother about the things I do online now!

media.media_title::eng: How can calm consequences help you and your family?
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone.

Even if you do everything right, your child will misbehave sometimes. We may be tempted to scream and shout, but that just leaves everyone more angry. 

If we stay calm, and give them a calm consequence, they will learn to take responsibility for their actions instead.

media.media_title::eng: Agreeing on consequences together works! Tap play to hear @data.characters.media_female_13.name's story
Did you know that playing is the best way to relax AND learn? Tap play to learn more
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone!
Do you know what is the best way to relax? Playing! 

And let’s be honest, which child does not like to play? 

Learning takes time, but there is a lot that you can do as a parent to help your child. Let them play and explore. Let them ask questions and learn from mistakes. And be patient. Your support will help them grow and develop.

media.media_title::eng: Play helped @data.characters.media_female_14.name and her son become closer. Tap play to hear how
media.media_transcript::eng:
My son was not really talking. I was worried about it but did not know how I could help him.

@global.app_name gave me lots of ideas for what I could do to help him develop at home. By playing together, we were able to practise many words in a fun way. He is speaking much more now, and we are closer because of the time we spend together.

media.media_title::eng: How will talking about feelings with your children help you and your family? Tap play to find out
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get really angry, upset and you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. You start with noticing and accepting all the emotions we have. We are all human.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_8.name taught her daughter skills by naming her emotions
media.media_transcript::eng:
My daughter used to get so frustrated and angry when she did not get her way. She would shout and scream, even when we went out, and I would also feel very angry and embarrassed. 

When I learned about emotions, I started to name and acknowledge her emotions. I helped her understand that it is okay to feel angry sometimes, but that she can show it in a different way. Now, she will tell me when she starts to feel angry, and we can find a solution together that works for everyone.

media.media_title::eng: Tap play to learn how giving positive instructions can help you and your family
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone.

Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them “stop fighting” or “stop playing with your food”, they don’t know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON’T want them to do.”

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_3.name learned to give her children positive instructions
media.media_transcript::eng:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learned about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “ don’t do this.” 
My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My child said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

media.media_title::eng: Why is spending one-on-one time with your child important? Tap play to learn
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone!

Our children don't need expensive gifts. The best gift we can give them is to spend one on one time with them.

By spending time together, you will understand your child better and they will learn many new things.

Having this time together with your child will feel special because it will help them feel loved and valued. That will make everything easier at home!

media.media_title::eng: Hear how one-on-one time helped @data.characters.media_female_1.name and her child connect
media.media_transcript::eng:
When I first heard I have to spend one-on-one time with my daughter, it was hard for me. I did not know when to do it or what to say. I did not want to spoil my daughter so that she thinks we have to do everything together. 

But I really wanted to build my relationship with her and I wanted her to open up about what was troubling her. 

So we tried the One-on-One Time. 

First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we play her favourite game together and talk about things happening at school and with her friends.

media.media_title::eng: Tap play to hear how praise can help you and your family
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

When was the last time you were praised? Can you praise yourself for something right now? Praise makes us all feel good. 

It is good to praise our children when they have done well, because when we do that, they will do more of that good behaviour we want to see.

And let's remember to praise ourselves too, for big or small things!

media.media_title::eng: Tap play to hear how simple praises helped @data.characters.media_female_2.name's family
media.media_transcript::eng:
When we learned about this praising thing, I thought “We were never praised for things as children, so why should we start now?”. But I got interested when I learned what the benefits of praising could be.

Right after learning about praise, I noticed my son doing what he does every day: Packing away his toys after playing. And I said “Thank you for packing away your toys, my boy, it really makes me happy that you are helping out to keep the house tidy.” My son was smiling and he even came to give me a hug, which he never does. 

This praising business is hard. I still forget to do it sometimes. But praising really makes a difference. I never thought that a simple praise could make such a change in a person!

media.media_title::eng: Tap play to hear how solving problems with your children can you and your family
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

As parents, it can feel like we have to solve a million problems for our children every day: Where is my toy car? I am not going to school! Why can’t you buy me new shoes now?

By involving our children in solving problems, they learn to find solutions more and more independently. 

Life has its challenges. If you help your child solve small problems today, you give them the skills to deal with any bigger challenges later in life.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_5.name and her daughter use the four steps of problem solving
media.media_transcript::eng:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school. 

Only when I started spending One-on-One Time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the four steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.

media.media_title::eng: Tap play to learn how rules and routines can help you and your family
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Do you have moments in the day with your child that feel stressful? Is it bedtime or getting ready for school?

Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

media.media_title::eng: Routines helped @data.characters.media_female_7.name and her family. Tap play to hear their story
media.media_transcript::eng:
Bedtime was always a struggle in our house. My children wanted to keep watching TV and I would always end up shouting at them: “Go to bed now! You know you have to be ready for school early in the morning!”. Some days I was just too tired, and I would let them watch more TV. 

When we learned in @global.app_name about rules, I learned that it is important to be consistent. I discussed with my children why watching TV till late is a problem, and we came up with a rule together to switch off the TV at 8 and be ready for bed by 8.30. Now everyone knows what is expected of them, and we can end the day peacefully.

media.media_title::eng: How will caring for yourself help you and your family? Listen to find out
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

There are times when we experience challenges, face problems, and do not know what to do. It is important to take care of ourselves every day, so we are ready to handle those times well and stay calm. 

When we are calm, we are in a good state to think positively and come up with positive solutions to any challenges we may be facing.

media.media_title::eng: Self care works! Hear @data.characters.media_male_1.name’s story
media.media_transcript::eng:
For me as a parent, it was almost impossible to find time for myself. I was always busy taking care of everyone else. Through @global.app_name, I realised how important it is to take care of myself. It helps me AND my family! 

Having a moment for myself helps me to breathe and notice how I feel. Even five minutes to have a cup of tea makes a big difference. Now I can deal with my stress better.

media.media_title::eng: How will praise help you and your family? Tap play to find out!
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings everyone.

Our topic today is about praise.

It is good to praise our children when they've done good because when we do that, they will do more of that good behavior we want to see.

And let's not forget to praise ourselves when we do good!

media.media_title::eng: Praise works, but it’s not always easy. Hear how @data.characters.media_female_2.name started using it at home
media.media_transcript::eng:
When we learnt about this praising thing I thought, “We were never praised for things as teenagers, so why should we start now?” But I got interested when I learnt what the benefits of praising could be.

Right after the weekly workshop, I noticed my teen doing what they do every day: washing the dishes. And I said “Thank you for washing the dishes, my girl, it really makes me happy that you are helping out.” My teen was smiling and she even came to give me a hug, which she never does.

This praising business is hard. I still forget sometimes or give praise at the same time as criticism. But praising really makes a difference. I never thought that a simple praise could make such a change in a person!

media.media_title::eng: Hear from @data.characters.media_daughter_2.name on how it feels to get praise from her mother
media.media_transcript::eng:
I was grateful that my mother learnt about praise.

My mother always noticed when I was doing something wrong. She would shout at me and hit me.

But when my mother did the workshop, she would praise me for little things. First I thought “What is going on?” but then it continued. I liked it so I did more good things I thought she would like.

It feels great that my mother sees the good things I do, and not just the bad things.

I even said it to her once. During one-on-one time, I said “Thank you, mom, for saying something nice when I do things well, not only when I do things wrong.” This made us both very happy.

media.media_title::eng: Should rules be important for you and your family? Click play to find out
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is rules.

Rules promote peace within the household and promote understanding amongst family members.

Rules promote responsibilities for each family member; therefore, it is important to have family rules.

A household with family rules lives in peace.

media.media_title::eng: Rules worked for @data.characters.media_female_7.name and her teens. Tap play to hear more
media.media_transcript::eng:
My teenagers always just disappeared. I did not know where they were and I would get so worried and angry with them. I used to say, “This is my house, and these are my rules, if you do not want to follow them you can leave and stay in your own place.”

When we learnt in @global.app_name about rules, I learnt that there are rules for teens and for adults and for everyone. If we follow the rules as parents, our teens will follow our example.

I explained my worry and we all agreed: We all follow the rule and say where we are going when we leave the house. Coming up with rules together helped us a lot, as my teens do not see me anymore as that annoying parent that just makes up unnecessary rules.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @global.app_name helped @data.characters.media_son_4.name talk honestly with his parents
media.media_transcript::eng:
As teens, we hear all these things about sex from others at school and on the internet. A few of my friends said they were already having sex, and I kept hearing that having sex makes you a real man and not a little boy. I believed it and I was afraid to tell my parents.
 
When we did @global.app_name, we made a family rule to share questions at home instead of keeping secrets. When I told my parents what I heard, they listened calmly and helped me understand what it means to have sex and be a man, and that real friends never pressure you to do anything.

Whenever I have a question or problem now, I know I can ask my parents and they will help me think of answers and find solutions together.

media.media_title::eng: Why is spending one-on-one time with your teens important? Tap play to learn
media.media_transcript::eng:
Hello.

Our topic today is one-on-one time with our children.

It is important to spend time with our children so that they can get to understand us, and for us to get an opportunity to understand them.

Remember, a family with good understanding lives in harmony.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how one-on-one time helped @data.characters.media_female_1.name and her teen
media.media_transcript::eng:
When I first heard I had to spend One-on-One Time with my teen, it was hard for me. I did not know when to do it or what to say. I did not want to spoil my teen so that he thinks we have to do everything together.

But I really wanted to build my relationship with my teen and I wanted him to open up about what was troubling him. So we tried the One-on-One Time.

First, it felt weird, but it turned out to be fun! Now we watch his TV programme together and we chat about it. And we can even talk about how my son is changing into adolescence and even about girlfriends and those things!

media.media_title::eng: Here's what @data.characters.media_daughter_1.name has to say about one-on-one time with her mother
media.media_transcript::eng:
When my mother asked to spend time with me, I thought “Maybe something is wrong, maybe she is sick.” But she said “No, I just want to spend time.” I was sceptical, but I accepted.

She asked me what I like doing. It was strange and I was not comfortable, because she never ever spent time with me on my own.

The more she kept on trying and we spent this time together, it felt really nice. She got to share her own childhood with me, things I never heard before. That helped me to also share what is going on in my life. We even talk about boyfriends and about problems I have. I know I can talk to my mother now.

media.media_title::eng: How will caring for yourself help you and your family? Listen to find out
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is self-care.

There are times when we experience challenges, face problems and do not know what to do. It is important to take care of ourselves to learn the techniques for keeping ourselves calm, in case problems, challenges or issues come up.

When we are calm we are in a good state to think positively and come up with positive solutions to any challenges we may be facing.

media.media_title::eng: Self care works! Hear @data.characters.media_female_14.name’s story
media.media_transcript::eng:
For me as a parent, it was almost impossible to find time for myself. I was always busy taking care of everyone else. Through @global.app_name, I realised how important it is to take care of myself. It helps me AND my family!

Having a moment for myself helps me to breathe and notice how I feel. Even 5 minutes to have a cup of tea makes a big difference. Now I can deal with my stress better.

media.media_title::eng: Can skills to handle crises help your family? Click play to find out
media.media_transcript::eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is dealing with crises.

Crisis may occur anywhere. Crisis may occur anytime. Therefore, it is important as a family to have plans in place should any family member find themselves in a crisis situation.

It is important to have plans so that every family member may feel protected.

When we are dealing with crises, remember to take a pause, breathe and keep yourself calm. That will help you to deal with crises better.

media.media_title::eng: @data.characters.media_female_9.name and her teen learned to handle crises together. Hear their story
media.media_transcript::eng:
My teen used to be so angry all the time. He would never listen and we would get into big arguments every day. Through @global.app_name, I started spending more time with my teen and strengthening our relationship. One day he shared with me that he was part of a gang but he wanted to get out.

We made short-term and long-term plans together on how we could do that. Our life looks so different now!

media.media_title::eng: Remember @data.characters.media_male_1.name? Here’s what his son says about his father practising self care
media.media_transcript::eng:
My dad was always busy. He would come home from work and snap at us when we started asking him questions.

@global.app_name helped us a lot. We no longer fight. Now, when my dad comes home, he first sits down by himself for 5 minutes and then we do a relaxing activity from @global.app_name together, so we can all take a deep breath and relax. Then we can chat about our day, about anything good or bad that happened. Everyone is so much happier now.

media.media_title::eng: @data.characters.media_daughter_12.name overcame a difficult crisis with the help of her mother. Tap play to learn how
media.media_transcript::eng:
Two years ago, I was raped by my uncle who stayed in our yard. I did not tell my mother, because I was afraid she would hit me, shout at me, or even throw me out of the house. I did not have anywhere else to go.

When my mother started with @global.app_name, we started spending more time together. I was still afraid, but in the end I shared it with my mother. My mom did not shout, but she listened and told me it is not my fault. We went to the police and the clinic together. I am so grateful I do not have to carry this secret anymore.

media.media_title::eng: Why is discussing online safety with your teen important? Click play to find out.
media.media_transcript::eng:
Our teens spend a lot of time online — watching videos, learning, and chatting with friends. The internet can be a great place to learn and connect, but it also comes with risks.

Did you know 1 in 3 young people have been bullied online? Some are even pressured to share private photos or personal information.

We can’t stop everything that happens online. But we can listen, stay calm, and let our teens know they can always come to us. When they feel safe to talk to us, we can help them stay safer.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_male_1.name learned to talk to his son about online safety
media.media_transcript::eng:
My son was always on his phone, but I did not pay too much attention to it. To be honest, I was busy with other things and happy he was safely at home and not out on the streets. The only time we spoke about his phone was when I was taking it away as punishment for something he did. 

The SinovuyoApp helped me realize that the online world is big and can have good and bad sides. We can now talk about what he does online, and we have created rules together to ensure he can enjoy his time online and still stay safe. His phone is no longer a punishment tool but a way we can connect.

media.media_title::eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_daughter_9.name’s mother helped her keep safe online
media.media_transcript::eng: Someone took my photo and put it on a naked body in a video. I freaked out and didn’t want to tell anyone, because I thought my parents would just take my phone away. But when my mom saw I was upset and asked, she stayed calm. We reported it together and got the video taken down. Now I know I don’t have to deal with things like this by myself.

quizes.feedback_3::eng: Parenting online is not easy. By carefully giving freedom while offering guidance, you can help your son or daughter learn while staying safe.

quizes.feedback_2::eng: Blaming breaks trust. Teens make mistakes, and feeling ashamed can make the situation worse. What matters most is helping @data.characters.f1_son_18.name feel safe and supported.
quizes.feedback_3::eng: Yes! Stay calm and listen. Tell @data.characters.f1_son_18.name it’s not his fault. Block and report if you can, and plan together what to do if photos are shared. If there’s anyone you both trust, ask them for help.

quizes.question::eng: How should @data.characters.friend_male_4.name’s mother respond?
quizes.feedback_1::eng: Denying the problem may feel easier, but it makes the situation worse. It is better to face the issue calmly, so you can understand what happened and give both children the support they need.
quizes.feedback_2::eng: Saying “boys will be boys” makes harmful behaviour seem normal. This stops children from understanding the real consequences of their actions.
quizes.feedback_3::eng: Getting very angry can shame your teen and close the door to learning. He may only feel fear, without understanding why it was wrong.
quizes.feedback_4::eng: Correct. By staying calm and listening, you help your teen feel safe to talk. This gives you a chance to explain why sharing sexual pictures or videos is harmful and guide him to make better choices in the future.

quizes.question::eng: Are sexual pictures or videos only shared by boys?

Boys are often more involved in this, but girls can be too.
Teach your teen to respect others and ask before sharing photos or videos. Explain that sharing or watching sexual content can hurt people.
Remind them it’s illegal to share any nude or sexual images of anyone under 18 — even their own.
