quizes.question::eng: What would you do if you were grandfather?
quizes.feedback_1::eng: Ignoring the problem may seem easiest, but it can put teens in danger. Strangers can use personal details from a profile as well as gifts to trick or pressure children.
quizes.feedback_2::eng: Yes! Ask @data.characters.f2_son_15.name what happened, what information he shared, and how he felt. Then guide him on safe choices like keeping profiles private and not replying to strangers.
quizes.feedback_3::eng: Getting angry may scare @data.characters.f2_son_15.name and shut down openness. He may hide future problems instead of asking for help. Stay calm so he knows he can trust you.
quizes.feedback_4::eng: Forcing may feel like protecting @data.characters.f2_son_15.name, but it can break trust and lead him to hide things in the future. A better way is to sit together, talk through the risks, and agree on safe solutions as a team.
quizes.feedback_5::eng: That’s right! Use this as a chance to explain why accepting gifts or sharing personal details (like school or uniform) online is unsafe. Explore together how to block and report strangers, and remind your teen they can always come to you if something feels wrong.

quizes.question::eng: Can you create and try out your Online Family Agreement this week?
quizes.feedback_1::eng: Making the agreement together shows your teen that online safety is about teamwork. You can always change or update your agreement later as well.
quizes.feedback_2::eng: Give it a try. Involving your teen in choosing the rules helps them feel respected and makes it more likely they will follow them. You can start with just one rule and add more later.
quizes.feedback_3::eng: That’s okay. You can start small. Even agreeing on just one rule together is a good first step. You can always add more ideas later on.

sections.text::eng:
Breathe slowly. Pause.

Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out five times. It will calm you, and give you a chance to think.

Share how you feel.

This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry, or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress.

Show them you care.

This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say "I understand". It can change everything.

Seek the positive.

Can you and your teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?
Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.
Smile, look them in the eye and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!
Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home on time’.
Keep meeting regularly to give each other parenting support.
Be ‘parenting buddies’ to call when you are upset or do not know what to do.
Text each other every week to share what you have done well.

Check you are both calm. Take a few breaths. Explain to your teen why you are concerned about their behaviour.

Explain the reasons why the rule mattered. You can share your feelings – it is okay to say you are disappointed.
sections.extra_text::eng: How you introduce calm consequences is important. When you involve your teen, things usually go better!

sections.text::eng:
Plan consequences with your teen for following and not following the rule.

Ask for their ideas. Talk until you agree on something realistic.

Make a consequence for NOT following the rule and a privilege when they DO follow the rule.
sections.extra_text::eng: Remember, consequences are more successful if you discuss and agree in advance with teens before you apply them.

sections.text::eng:
**When your teen follows the rule, give praise and privileges!** 
They will feel respected and valued. Remember: The more we praise them, the more they will show that good behaviour!


**When your teen does not follow the rule, follow through with the consequence.** 
When your teen breaks the rule, calmly give the consequence. This should be FAIR (not too harsh), IMMEDIATE (do it straight away), CONSISTENT (same every time).
sections.extra_text::eng: Remember, you can also agree on GOOD consequences for GOOD actions to see more positive behaviour!

sections.text::eng:
**What do we spend on now?**

Write down or draw what you spend money on as a family each month. 

How much does each item cost? 
How much money do you need in total?

**Talk together about needs and wants.**

Which expenses are a ‘need’ that you cannot live without? 
Which expenses are a ‘want’ that is nice to have but not essential? 
Which things could you try to spend less on? 

When we explain and listen to each other carefully, we can make good money choices together as a family.

**Make your own budget.**
Write down your income for the month. 
Take stones, beans, or anything with lots of bits - this is your income. 
Agree how much you will spend on each item, and put the objects on that image/word.

Plan for emergencies and family goals.

Draw a circle ‘emergencies’.
Draw a circle ‘saving’.
Move your ‘money’ around so you can save a bit every month for both.
sections.extra_text::eng: Remind your teen to always tell you or a trusted adult if someone offers them gifts, airtime, money, or deals that are ‘too good to be true’ - online or offline - especially if asked for photos, favours, or to keep secrets.

sections.text::eng: Identify the problem.
Think of possible solutions and what would happen if we used them.
Choose a solution and try it out.
Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

Make maps with your teen of safe and unsafe areas in your community and online. Talk about how to keep their information, photos and videos private online. Talk about how once something goes online, it stays there forever. They might know an example from their friends.
Make rules with your teen about how they can stay safe in your community (especially in risky areas that cannot be avoided), and how they can safely use the apps and websites that they like.
sections.extra_text::eng: Explore with your teen if you can create a rule around sharing with a trusted adult when something feels wrong. This can really help them stay safe in person and online.

sections.text::eng: Agree on a Safety Word. If something happens that makes your teen upset, uncomfortable or scared, they can say the Safety Word and you will help them without getting angry or punishing them, even if they were doing something wrong.
sections.extra_text::eng:
What Safety Word can you choose with your teen? Here are some ideas from other families:

🥑 A specific food
👵🏽 A specific family member
🐒 A specific animal
🤔 Something else

sections.text::eng:
Take some deep breaths or walk away from the situation if you need to.

Then, respond in a calm, clear way.
sections.extra_text::eng: Shouting at our children only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.

sections.text::eng: Give a consequence connected to the behaviour, and make sure it is something you can follow through with.
sections.extra_text::eng:
For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

If your child is experiencing a natural consequence for their action (like not being able to play with their toy after breaking it), you might not need to give them an additional consequence.

sections.text::eng: Follow through with a consequence every time a rule is broken, even if it feels small. Being consistent shows your child you mean what you say and helps them take the rules seriously.
sections.extra_text::eng: If you miss a chance to follow through, do not worry – just try again next time.

sections.text::eng: Ask your child what a fair consequence might be if a rule is not followed. This helps them learn responsibility and makes it more likely they will stick to the rule.
sections.extra_text::eng: You can also involve your child in choosing simple and free rewards for their behaviours. This will encourage them to follow the rules more often!

sections.text::eng:
Play helps children develop important physical and social skills. 

Set aside time to play games with your child, be creative, and have fun together. Remember, through play, you also learn what kind of support your child may need.
sections.extra_text::eng:
You can support your child to play and make friends with other children, so they learn how to interact with others well. 

If your child starts to feel overwhelmed with anything in their day, help them reduce their stress by taking a pause and playing together.

sections.text::eng:
Learning new things takes time. Be patient and encourage your child to keep trying, even when things feel hard. 

Stay calm when they get angry or frustrated – your child will learn to do the same over time.
sections.extra_text::eng:
You can support them by praising them for trying, and helping them break large tasks into smaller tasks that are appropriate for their age.

Use play to help your child learn difficult skills, like losing, sharing, or taking turns.

sections.text::eng: Children learn by asking questions and exploring the things they are interested in. Give your child time and space to do this, and be patient when they make mistakes. We all learn from our mistakes!
sections.extra_text::eng:
Your child may talk a lot and have many questions –  including difficult ones. You can give your child short but honest answers. 

If you need a break or more information, you can take a pause and tell your child you will respond to them later.

sections.text::eng: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.
sections.extra_text::eng: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child’s words and actions.

sections.text::eng: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.
sections.extra_text::eng:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
😊 Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

☹️ Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

😠 Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

🤢 Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

😯 Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

😨 Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

sections.text::eng:
Use words to describe your and your child’s emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!
sections.extra_text::eng:
Describe how you see your child’s emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*“I notice you’re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?”*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*“I know, I feel the same way when I can’t go out when I want to.”*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

sections.text::eng:
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
But before you do that, connect to them, so they are more likely to listen.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Use your child’s name to get their attention. Go down to their level. Make eye contact.

Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: “Please take your shoes off when you come inside, dear”.

sections.text::eng: Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do.
sections.extra_text::eng: Giving a transition warning helps when you are asking them to change activities! For example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.”

sections.text::eng:
Try using positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of “Don’t shout inside”, say “Talk in a quiet voice when we’re inside.” 

ALWAYS praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction. This will make them more likely to repeat the behaviour and listen to you next time!
sections.extra_text::eng:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.

Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

sections.text::eng:
Spend at least 5 minutes a day with your child.
More time is even better!

Turn off the TV, put down your phone, and remove distractions.
Show your child you’re really listening and paying attention!
sections.extra_text::eng:
- Look at your child. Get down to their level. Use their name.
- Describe what they are doing and feeling. Praise them.
- Your child will learn a lot from what you say and do.

sections.text::eng: Let your child choose what to do or talk about. It helps them feel important. Ask to spend time together and try fun (or even silly!) activities.
Look for good behaviours that you can praise! It can be anything positive or helpful your child does or tries to do.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Pause and really notice when they are doing something positive. Even if it’s expected of them.

Praise your child for *trying*. This boosts their self-esteem and confidence, which helps them to learn new behaviours.

sections.text::eng: Praise them when you see them do something you like. Do this every day – even if it’s something really small.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Tell them specifically what they have done well.

Be enthusiastic and really mean it!

You can show your praise with a big smile and words.

sections.text::eng: Give your child a simple, free reward to encourage them to do more of the behaviours that may be difficult for them.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Give your child a hug, extra playtime together, or make their favourite meal. 

Simple rewards can be a big motivation for your child to keep trying and show more positive behaviour.

sections.text::eng:
Put the problem into words.

Talk to your child about what the problem is.
sections.extra_text::eng: _"I can hear you arguing because you don’t want to watch the same television programme. I know I said you both could watch TV after you’ve helped clean up after dinner, but we only have one television. How can we solve this problem?"_

sections.text::eng:
Together, think of possible solutions to this problem.
What could you or your child do differently in this situation in the future?
sections.extra_text::eng: _"One option is for us not to turn the television on at all. You can also take turns choosing a programme or select one you both want to watch. What do you both think?"_

sections.text::eng:
Choose one solution together.

Try it next time you are in a similar situation, and praise your child for trying!
sections.extra_text::eng:
_"Okay boys, do you remember what we said last night about the TV? Who can remember the solution we came up with?"
"That's right – well done for remembering! Let's try to pick a programme that you both want to watch – I can even come watch with you!"_

sections.text::eng: After you’ve tried it, decide with your child whether or not your solution worked.
sections.extra_text::eng: After the programme ends… _“Well that was an exciting game! I never knew I liked watching soccer so much, so thank you for introducing me to something new! I think we all had fun watching that together.”_

sections.text::eng: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.

sections.text::eng:
Consider your child’s age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time – you can add another one later.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Start with small and clear rules your child can follow. If a rule feels too hard, work together to break it into smaller steps.

Make rules realistic for what your child can do. Be specific – instead of “clean up,” say “put your blocks away.”

sections.text::eng:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.
sections.extra_text::eng: Activities become easier when children learn and get comfortable with the routine.

sections.text::eng: Taking a pause helps us to feel and respond calmer in stressful moments.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Even taking a few deep breaths makes a big difference. 

By staying calm instead of reacting strongly, you can also prevent a lot of problems!

sections.text::eng: Take a moment and think of one thing YOU did well recently. Say it aloud if you can: _"Well done for …"_
sections.extra_text::eng:
Being a parent can be hard. Praise yourself for trying your best. 

Identify negative thoughts when they start and decide if they are true or helpful. If not, find positive thoughts to replace them with. 

For example, instead of “I am a bad parent” say “I am feeling overwhelmed right now, but I am doing the best I can and I will talk to a friend for support”.

sections.text::eng: What makes you happy? Find small things that you can do every day to care for yourself.
sections.extra_text::eng: Doing something you enjoy will give you a short break. It will help you to think more clearly and care better for your family. Caring for yourself = caring for your family!

sections.text::eng: Look for anything your teen does that is helpful or good — whether that’s online or offline — and praise them for it. They may not show it, but you’ll see them do that good thing again. It also shows them that you notice and care.
Be enthusiastic – really mean it when you say it!
Try to find something to thank them for every day. Even something really small.

This module includes content that may be sensitive. You can check it out by yourself first. This will prepare you well for sharing the content with your teen and others afterwards.

If you need support, see the “Support Contacts” section in your Library for help.
Household rules help to keep our teenagers safe and to understand what is expected from them. When you involve a teenager in making rules they are more likely to follow them.
sections.extra_text::eng: Include rules for healthy relationships and safe online habits — like sharing openly, showing respect, using phones responsibly, and talking to a trusted adult if something feels wrong.

sections.text::eng: Plan rules WITH your teenager. Start with one new rule first – you can add another one later. Discuss the reasons for the rule and listen to their views.
sections.extra_text::eng: Talk with your teen about why rules are important both online and offline.

sections.text::eng: Praise your teen for planning a rule with you, and praise them for keeping it! Positive feedback helps teens make good choices, including in relationships and online.

Teens learn about sex and relationships from many places, and some information may be incorrect or not right for their age.

Talk calmly about body changes, respect, and consent.

Listen without judging, and guide your teen to make safe choices in relationships and online.
sections.extra_text::eng: You do not need to have all the answers. You can ask other adults or health workers for help and information.

sections.text::eng:
Try to do it every day. 

Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.
sections.extra_text::eng: Many short moments of connection each day or week help build trust and give you more chances to guide your teen than long, serious conversations.

sections.text::eng:
Let your teen choose.

Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but they will come to enjoy this time with you!
sections.extra_text::eng: One-on-one time can also help you understand your teen’s online world better. Get involved by asking “Did you come across anything exciting online today?” or “Can you show me how to do a group call on WhatsApp?

sections.text::eng:
Focus on your teen.

Switch off the TV and put phones aside. Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show that you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

One-on-one time also helps your teen learn. They learn best when they feel connected and supported. Spend time with them online and offline. Encourage them to try, and be patient with mistakes. Praise their efforts so they feel safe, confident, and motivated to keep learning.

If you need support, see the “Support Contacts” section in your Library for help.

Do a 30 second quick relaxation activity.
sections.extra_text::eng:
Take a moment now to relax. Breathe in slowly as you count to three... and breathe out as you count to three. Feel your body relax with each breath. 

Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and need a break. A few calm breaths can make a big difference.

sections.text::eng:
Think of one thing YOU have done well recently.

_"Well done to me for..."_
sections.extra_text::eng:
It could be showing love to your children, helping them with schoolwork, or preparing a meal even when you felt tired. 

Every small effort you make matters, and you get to celebrate yourself.

sections.text::eng: Remember, you deserve your “me time” too! What makes you happy?
sections.extra_text::eng:
It could be something small, like enjoying a cup of tea, taking a short nap, chatting with a friend, or listening to your favourite music.

Spending time with your teen can be fun for you too! It might even make you feel less stressed.

sections.text::eng: Help other parents, including your partner, to take care of themselves, and ask them to do the same for you.
sections.extra_text::eng: Share chores, give each other time to rest, or remind each other to take breaks. When parents support each other, the whole community benefits — and teens learn self-care matters, too.

sections.text::eng: Make sure your teen knows they can talk to you about anything that happens online and offline, and if a crisis happens, you will handle it together.
Stay calm. Ask yourself, "What does my teen need right now?"
Tell them you are there for them and love them.
Talk with your teen. What might help the situation? Reach out to the available support around you, in your community, and online.
sections.extra_text::eng: You might need to make immediate plans now and then long-term plans later. Remember, you can find Support Contacts in the @global.app_name Library.

sections.text::eng:
This module includes sensitive topics and offers tips to help keep your teen safe online.
If your teen has faced something difficult or you’re worried about their behaviour, you are not alone.
You can call Childline at 116 for free, private help and advice.
Keeping accounts private, turning off location sharing, and using strong passwords helps stop strangers from seeing your teen’s information.

Help your teen stay safe by setting clear boundaries together. Remind them to only talk to people they know offline, and explore together how to block and report anyone who makes them feel uncomfortable. Agree on simple family rules, like device-free times at meals or bedtime.

Help your teen recognise unsafe signs, like someone asking for photos, offering money, or suggesting to keep secrets. These are warning signs of danger. Remind your teen they can always ask for help if something feels wrong. They can ask you, a teacher, another trusted adult, or Childline (call 116).
Remind your teen that once something is online, it can spread quickly. Encourage them not to post or share private photos or personal details.

Show interest in what your teen enjoys online. Ask what they see online and what they think about it - this builds critical thinking and helps them feel heard. 

**Listen without judging**, and talk about **safe boundaries**, like only talking to people they know offline. **Stay calm** if something goes wrong and remind them they can always come to you. Teens are more likely to share when they feel safe and trusted.
sections.extra_text::eng: Teens often tell friends first. Ask your teen what they would do if a friend was in danger online. Remind them it’s okay to involve a trusted adult.

sections.text::eng:
Remind your teen to **think before posting**. 💭
Once something is online, it can spread fast and be hard to delete.

Teach them to **ask before sharing** anyone’s photo or info — and show this by doing it yourself.
Private or sexual pictures should never be shared.

Encourage your teen to remind friends to stay safe too — **friends can help friends make good choices**.

Watch for warning signs that something may be wrong. 🚨

Your teen might be quiet, hide their phone, or spend much more time online. Someone may ask them to share photos, keep secrets, or offer them presents like money or airtime.

If something unsafe happens, **don’t blame or punish** your teen. Instead, **block and report** together, remind them it’s not their fault, and get help from Childline (116), teachers, or another trusted adult.

If your teen has hurt others online, stay calm. Help them see the harm and learn to do better — **without shame or anger**.
sections.extra_text::eng: Solving problems together works better than punishing. Support is available, and you are not alone.

sections.text::eng: Keep your teen’s online spaces safe. Sit together and set accounts to private, turn off location sharing, and use strong passwords. Remind them not to share their phone number, home address, school name or photos in school uniform. Explore together how to block and report anyone who makes them feel uncomfortable.
sections.extra_text::eng: Blocking and reporting strangers helps protect teens from unsafe people online, including those who trick them by pretending to be friendly.
